Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A vendor sent a standard automated confirmation of a recent payment, to which a formal reply should be sent.
Story: It’s Saturday afternoon, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Call us when you can.” I glance at the clock—almost three. I haven’t spoken to my parents in over a week, and I know they expect me to check in, even if it’s just a quick call. I start typing a reply, but my work phone vibrates. An email from a vendor pops up: a payment confirmation, routine but requiring a formal acknowledgment. My manager always stresses the importance of prompt, professional communication, even on weekends. I feel the pressure mounting—my parents want to hear my voice, to know I’m okay, while my job demands immediate attention to keep things running smoothly. I stare at both screens, my fingers hovering, torn between sending a warm message home or drafting a polished reply to the vendor. The weight of both expectations presses down, and for a moment, I just sit there, caught between being a good son and a responsible accountant.
